section.name: Installation
section.p: The Installation can be done anywhere wanted. On Unix like System an installation directory like /opt/JavaApp is suitable. Within this directory place the kickstart.jar and the KickStart.properties file (beware of small and capital letters in Unix OS). Additionally, some directories need to be added to place the actual libraries into it. A recommendation is to create the following sub-directories:

ul.li: bin: Within this directory all executable scripts are located which actually start KickStart and choose the Class in which the needed main() method can be found for startup.
config: This directory should be treated as class library directory and is used for configuration files which are placed into the CLASSPATH and loaded as resource.
extlib: To extlib all libraries from external vendors should go in.
lib: Should be the directory where all classes go in which are from own developments and which are changed during development cycles.
log: Within this directory all log files which are generated by the tools should be located. KickStart itself does not generate any log files.

section.p: All directory naming is meant to be inside the installation directory of the KickStart framework.

section.name: Additional System Configuration
section.p: In the next sections some information is given beyond the normal KickStart setup to include the Java application more deeply into the OS.

subsection.name: PATH Variable
subsection.p: On Unix one adds KickStart to a global PATH variable by changing /etc/profile , /etc/profile , /etc/bash.bashrc or /etc/bash.bashrc.local . The location depends on the System used. For user related changes the files ~/.profile or ~/.bashrc should be checked.
For Windows in the System Control Panel the path can be adjusted.

subsection.name: Usage in Cron
subsection.p: To add the KickStart bin directory into the Cron PATH variable modify /etc/crontab and add a line like PATH=/usr/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin:/bin:/usr/lib/news/bin .
